text: hi everyone Bethany coughed anno here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new
lightning bolt album sonic Citadel
legendary noise rock duo lightning bolt
Bryan Chippendale and Brian Gibson they
are back following up 2014's
fantasy Empire for over 20 years now the
Bryan's have been creating some of the
most delightful sonic mayhem within all
of noise rock with just drums and bass
mostly together they had been
responsible for some of the most
crushing and psychedelic records in the
genre from the 2000s really of all time
wonderful rainbow Earthly Delights also
hyper Magic Mountain a record that I
love despite the fact that more often
than not when I listen to this album all
the way through I get a head splitting
migraine
it's sad that in recent years Lightning
volts output seems to have slowed down a
little bit the new stuff is not as
aggressive or as explosive as the old
stuff however I would love to hear a
record we're lightening both is
capturing their former glory once again
and I gotta say sonic Citadel is a
pretty welcome addition to their
catalogue and astonishingly they don't
achieve this by pushing their sound to
another level of insanity lightning bolt
actually reels it in a little bit on
this one not hitting listeners with as
many frantic finger taps on that bass
neck not as many overdubs or layers or
loops it's like the Brian's are breaking
it back down to the simplicity of the
wonderful rainbow era from here the duo
starts delivering songs with clearer
structures a bit more melody a smidge of
method two lightning bolts usual madness
Chippendales vocals on this record feel
a lot less like a demented person
yelling at you through the talkbox of a
McDonald's drive-thru and more like
somebody who's really trying to hold a
tune under that occasionally Gibson's
bass riffs are a little steady follow a
very straightforward chord structure
whether you're talking about whose skirt
don't or Don Henley
in the park especially all insane now
this shift in tone is not amazing from
front to back on the project personally
I think some of Chippendales vocals can
feel a little tedious these singing on
USA is a psycho is just okay
while the melodies and head-bobbing
grooves once again on all insane
do get very repetitive very fast for the
most part this track is a really
straightforward rock song and while I do
admire lightning bolt for trying it I
don't know if a track of this style is
really in their skill set especially
since the recording and the mix doesn't
exactly show the dynamics that maybe a
four piece or a five piece would display
playing a track that is equally as
simple thankfully this more melodic
shift in tone benefits more tracks on
the album than it doesn't the track
Husker don't is easily one of my
favorite lightning-bolt tracks ever now
Chippendales vocals on this one have a
classic punky quality to them the bass
tone and usual lightning bolt fashion is
grimy as hell and I love the just
cascading raining down of harmonized
fiery screaming bass leads that pop in
in between each verse also the way the
whole thing shits around the second half
with that amazing epic descending bass
line is great not to mention the
de-evolution into just disheveled chaos
for the last minute or so the song Don
Henley is almost meditative in a way
with Gibson playing his bass at a very
high pitch and with these lines these
chords these phrasings that are very
jeroni it's almost like he's playing a
sitar especially toward the start of the
whole thing where his bass is sounding
particularly thin and jangly it mostly
evolves into a mess during the last leg
that when it could have gone somewhere
more interesting
now while sonic Citadel does show a
slightly sweeter side of lightning bolt
no doubt there are still plenty of
tracks here that sound like the
soundtrack to a hailstorm of asteroids
breaking through Earth's atmosphere
unscathed to completely tear apart the
Earth's surface and just leave all life
on this planet obliterated the song big
banger is literally what the title
describes loudest song on the record I
would wager maybe one of the loudest and
lightning bolts discography with total
blown out drums these trippy delayed
lead vocals just swimming in this very
compressed noisy mix these bass riffs
that are just sliding the world they
just sound like hundreds of giant
motorcycles revving up it's just one of
those lightning bolt tracks that grooves
on this one insane a weird idea for a
very long time thankfully we do get some
tension release transitioning out of
this at one point with some quickly
strum chords mystical lead melodies it's
like we've suddenly transitioned into a
desert or something and we're just
trying to survive a really intense
sandstorm the song blow to the head the
intro to this thing features some
speedily rolling drums booming hits a
bass easily some of the most exciting
noise rock I've heard this year the
triumphant bass leads on this track and
vocals add an epic melody to an already
gigantic sounding mix also the very
messy and everything but the kitchen
sink bridge on this track is
gratifyingly disturbing thankfully the
song air conditioned did grow on me at
first when I heard it I did not like it
at all
I chalk a lot of that up to the sound
quality of the first upload on Bandcamp
being very bad thankfully the better
fidelity version that I'm hearing on
streaming services sounds great loving
the very nutty lead vocals on this track
the righteous chords the intense flurry
of drums that pop in on the chorus in a
lot of ways this track is a classic
lightning bolt formula but performed
with some riffs and some ideas and some
writing that I haven't quite heard
before it's it's familiar but refreshing
I feel roughly the same way about
Halloween 3 there are some ideas on the
track that feel maybe a little deja vu
for lightning bolts but the performance
on that one is incredible as long as I'm
talking about moments on this record
that are a little predictable or
underwhelming though Tom thump is easily
one of the weakest links in the chain
throughout the tracklist as it is quite
obviously the most under written track
on the entire record I would argue there
are quite a few songs in the second half
that are kind of so-so bouncy house is
fantastic but then there's also Van
Halen when the father behind the closing
track on this thing which is over nine
minutes long whoo and this is an amazing
ending
to this record it's more of a journey
than it is a song lightning bolt has put
out some pretty long and indulgent songs
in their back catalogue over the years
and this is easily one of my favorite
closures they've ever done it starts out
like a very raw chaotic Jam with both
Brian's not really seeming like at first
they have too much of a concrete idea as
to where this is going
they're just basically both making a lot
of noise however the whole thing is
gaining more and more and more momentum
as it barrels forward into infinity
adding on more and more of these
unsettling dissonant layers eventually
we reach a point where this incredible
amount of momentum breaks and we're
getting more coherent riffs more of the
Brian's sounding like they're they're
more in sync with each other but still
the whole thing sounds incredibly
unhinged even some noises I haven't
quite heard on a lightning bolt record
before it sounds like um occasionally
there's some screaming blurting
harmonica what it's actually ingeniously
abrasive I'll say that again a fantastic
finish to the album and its oddity as a
track almost makes it indescribable
overall I thought this thing was a great
album I enjoyed it more than lightning
bolts last record I think that it is
pretty solid throughout a few lulls in
the tracklist here and there but a
really enjoyable admirable effort from
lightning bolt I don't prefer this one
to a lot of the group's classic stuff
but still they are trying a lot of new
things on this one and it's mostly
panning out I'm feeling a strong seven
to a light eight on this one transition
